div2.p: The Ethonology of Madagascar By Rev. B. F. Wheeler, A.M., D.D. Read Before the New York Ministers Meeting

Madagascar, as all are aware, lies off the south-east coast of the continent of Africa. To be a little more definite or explicit, we may say that by exact measurement it lies between 12* and 25* south latitude, and 42* and 51* east longitude.

With the exception of Borneo, Madagascar is the largest island in the worl. It is about 970 miles long and between 300 and 400 miles wide. To get a better idea of its size, it con- tains an area of 200,000 square miles, which would make it as large as England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, and the States of New York, New Hampshire, Massachusettes, Connecticut and Rhode Island combined.

The land is low along the coast, and this low, marshy land extends, inwardly for 30 or 40 miles. In the interior there is a broad table land. A range of mountains rises from this table land and extends North and South nearly the entire length of the island. It does not appear, however, as far as we have been able to find out, that the structure of these Ankasatia mountains is such as to make it possible for Madagascar even to be proven to be a continent, as Australia has been shown to be. Some of the mountain peaks rise 8000 and 12000 feet above the level of the sea.

There are abundant beautiful lakes and rivers throughout the island, but unfortunately none of the rivers are navigable. Undergrowth and shrubbery all over the island make traveling exceedingly difficult. There are no roads and it is the policy of the government never to have any constructed. This shrubbery and undergrowth furnish a good natural defense they claim, and make it impossible for an invading army ever to reach Tanana- rivo the capital of the island. Some of the largest forests in the world abound in this island.
